title: Elemental Technologies being acquired by Amazon Web Services
text:
Elemental Technologies being acquired by Amazon Web Services 
Technology Industry News.Net : Friday 4th September, 2015 
SEATTLE - Amazon Web Services, Inc., an Amazon company, has reached an agreement to acquire Elemental Technologies, Inc., pioneers in software-defined video solutions for multi screen content delivery, for an undisclosed sum. 
Bloomberg News citing a person with knowledge of the deal pegged it at more than $500 million. 
Techcrunch.com states that at $500 million, Elemental would represent one of Amazon's five biggest acquisitions to date. The others include Zappos, acquired in 2009 for $1.2 billion; Twitch, acquired last year for $970 million; Kiva Systems, acquired in 2012 for $775 million; and Quidsi, acquired for $545 million in 2010 
The acquisition, which is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2015, brings together Elemental's leading video solutions with the AWS Cloud platform to provide media and entertainment companies with a range of integrated solutions to economically scale video infrastructures as the media industry increasingly moves to internet based delivery. 
"Elemental shares Amazon's passion for invention and putting the customer first," said Andy Jassy, Senior Vice President of Amazon Web Services, in a statement Thursday. 
"Together, we'll collaborate on deeper technology integrations and new infrastructure offerings so that media and entertainment companies can evolve their hybrid and cloud models as they continue to innovate their services for viewers." 
Founded in 2006, Portland, Oregon headquartered Elemental software makes it easy for media and entertainment companies to take live and on-demand video destined for traditional networks like cable, satellite, or over-the-air broadcast and re-format that content for distribution to PCs, smart phones, tablets, and TVs. 
Elemental has more than 700 media franchise customers and powers some of the world's most popular over-the-top TV (OTT) applications, like the BBC's iPlayer, CNNGo, ESPN ScoreCenter, HBO GO, MSNBC Shift, and Sky Go and Sky Now. 
Elemental is also supporting the world's first 4K Ultra HD services including those that were delivered by the BBC during the 2014 World Cup. 
"The media and entertainment industry is at a unique inflection point, and as a part of Amazon, we will be in an even stronger position to help our customers delight their viewers globally," said Sam Blackman, co-founder and CEO of Elemental. "We're thrilled to have Amazon supporting our growth and ongoing commitment to our customers' success." 
Elemental will continue to operate under its existing brand, delivering the full range of solutions for pay TV operators, content programmers, broadcasters, governments, and enterprise customers. 
It will also expand the integration of its offerings with AWS, and through close collaboration with AWS, accelerate the innovation of next-generation services that feature a range of solutions for customers leveraging on-premises assets, hybrid architectures, and cloud.
